items.message:
This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  
Please see the GOV.UK website for a 5 day flood forecast.

River levels remain high but steady at the Mythe Bridge river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Monday 13/12/21. Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Severn from Tewkesbury to Gloucester. Locations that may be affected include Apperley and Maisemore. 
Mythe Bridge peaked at 2.84 metres and Haw Bridge peaked at 3.73 metres on Sunday evening 12/12/21.
Predicted peaks:- Sandhurst 2.4 – 2.7 metres  on Monday morning 13/12/21, Gloucester 2.1 – 2.4 metres on Monday morning 13/12/21.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 24 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high for several days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on Monday 13/12/21, or as the situation changes

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

River levels remain high as a result of heavy rainfall.  Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible today, Monday 13/12/21.  Flooding may affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Highley to Tewkesbury. Locations affected are Stourport, Holt Fleet, Worcester, Kempsey, Severn Stoke, Upton upon Severn, South Quay, Diglis Parade and Hylton Road towpath. Flooding from drains may affect the racecourse and Worcester County cricket ground. New Street gate and Severn Leisure, Waterside gate in Upton are closed.  
Bewdley peaked at 3.32m, Worcester peaked at 3.37m,  Diglis peaked at 2.87m, Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 5.0m and Saxons Lode peaked at 3.62m on Sunday, 12/12/21. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We are closely monitoring the situation.  Please avoid using low lying footpaths and roads near rivers, which may be flooded. 
This message will be updated by 5pm on 13/12/21, or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Llanymynech river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Flooding continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from the Welsh border at Llawnt to Shrawardine near Shrewsbury. Other locations that may be affected include Llanymynech, Maesbrook and Melverley. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. River levels at Maesbrook and Cae Howel are high but steady, but still pose a flood risk. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses. This message will be updated by 6 pm Monday 13/12/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels have risen at the Buildwas river gauge as a result of Storm Barra.  Flooding continues.  We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Shrewsbury to Upper Arley. Locations that may be affected are Coalbrookdale, Ironbridge and Bridgnorth. Floodplain at Leighton starts to fill. Crew Green peaked on Thursday, Montford peaked Friday morning, Welshbridge peaked at 3.4m Friday evening, Buildwas  peaked at 4.3m Saturday evening, Bridgnorth peaked at 3.4m Saturday evening.   
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  We expect river levels to remain high. 
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking defences.  
Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  
This message will be updated by 6pm Monday 13/12/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but steady at the Lugwardine river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland is possible. We expect flooding to affect Low lying land and roads adjacent to the River Lugg south of Leominster from Stoke Prior to Mordiford. Other locations that may be affected include Bodenham, Lugwardine and Hampton Bishop. Flooding of properties is not forecast at this point. Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high for the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. This message will be updated by 6 pm on Monday 13/12/21 or as the situation changes.

floodArea.riverOrSea: Sandyford Brook, Ridings Brook, Saredon Brook

items.message:
River levels remain high but steady at the Great Bridgford river gauge as a result the risk of flooding remains.  Flooding is affecting low-lying land and roads adjacent to the River Sow between Great Bridgeford and Shugborough, the River Penk between Coven and Stafford, the Sandyford Brook, the Rising Brook, the Ridings Brook and the Saredon Brook.   
The weather forecast remains unsettled and we expect levels to remain elevated in the coming days.
We are closely monitoring the situation.  Our incident response staff are clearing weed screens and actively checking river levels and the weather forecast.  
Please stay aware in case further warnings are issued and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded.  
This message will be updated tomorrow morning, 13/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: The tidal Rivers Bure, Ant and Thurne
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for a dry day.  There is a possibility of a small amount of rain tomorrow afternoon, but totals are expected to be low.  There is also the possibility of further tide-locking in the early hours of Tuesday 14 December. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

This Flood Alert has been removed.  
River levels have now fallen below the flood risk threshold.  We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert/warning if necessary.  Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours.  
We continue to monitor the situation.  Our incident response staff are checking the condition of defences.  
Please avoid contact with flood water.

items.message:
River levels are high but remain steady at the Tern - Walcot river gauge as a result of Storm Barra. Consequently, flooding of roads and farmland continues. We expect flooding to affect low lying land and roads adjacent to the river from Wolverley to Newport. Other locations that may be affected include Market Drayton, Wem and Rodington.
Further rainfall is forecast over the next 48 hours. We expect river levels to remain high over the next few days. We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and plan driving routes to avoid low lying roads near rivers, which may be flooded. Please avoid contact with flood water.
This message will be updated by 6pmm Monday 13/12/21 or as the situation changes.

River levels are high but falling at the Kempsey Yacht Club river gauge as a result of recent rainfall. Consequently, the risk of flooding remains. Flooding may affect low lying land and Squires walk in the area of the Hatfield Brook Kempsey. 
Kempsey Yacht Club peaked at 5.0m on Sunday, 12/12/21. 
Further rainfall is forecast over the next few days.  We expect river levels to remain high for several days.  We are closely monitoring the situation. Our incident response staff are checking defences. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses and avoid contact with flood water. This message will be updated by 5pm today, Monday 13/12/21, or as the situation changes.

items.description: River Dee catchment in England from Whitchurch to Chester

items.message:
This flood alert has been removed. River levels have fallen and there is no longer a risk of flooding. 
We will continue to monitor the forecast and re-issue this alert if necessary. 
Please be aware of your surroundings and keep up to date with the current situation.

items.description: The River Colne from Great Yeldham to Colchester
items.message: River levels are now returning to normal. The forecast is for a dry day.  There is a possibility of a small amount of rain tomorrow afternoon but totals at the moment are thought to be low. There may still be some areas where flood water is present until it can naturally drain away. Continue to take care on waterside roads and footpaths, and don't put yourself in unnecessary danger. We will continue to monitor levels closely.

items.description: Little Ouse River and River Thet in Suffolk and Norfolk
items.message:
River levels continue to fall but remain high at the Redbridge river gauge following recent rainfall. River levels continue to slowly rise at downstream gauges at Melford on the River Thet, and at Abbey Heath on the Little Ouse River. Consequently, flooding of property/roads and farmland is possible today, Monday 13 December.  We expect flooding to affect the Little Ouse River from Rickinghall to Hockwold, including The Black Bourn, and River Thet from Attleborough to Thetford.   
No significant rainfall is forecast for the next 24 hours.  

We are closely monitoring the situation. Please avoid using low lying footpaths near local watercourses.  

This message will be updated this afternoon, Monday 13 December, or as the situation changes.
